Traditional Brass Alang Dhuparti / Dhoop Aarti / Dhoop Stand by DMI

  [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Shri Dhanlaxmi Metals (DMI) Traditional Brass Alang Dhuparti[/caption]  

Why do we use Alang Dhuparti?

As per the customs followed, DMI Alang Dhuparti is specially used to put dhoop as well as Camphor. It is generally used in the home during pooja. Ancient literature states that burning dhoop purifies the air surrounding us and helps in building Ozone layer. It relieves stress, depression and anxiety.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7095,7096,7098,7097,7099,7100"]

Why should we buy this Alang Dhuparti?

Brass the so called auspicious metal popularly used for Pooja and other rituals is also known for enhancing the calmness and happiness in adornment. These are usually lit only in temples and divine places.

Finished with 60-65 % of Copper, this DMI Alang Dhuparti is perfect for gifting or donating to temples. It is designed keeping it simple making it easy to clean.

Name: DMI's two Faced Antique Brass Dasara Panti
Short description:
• Two face panti without stand/ base.
  • Made with more than 60 % of Copper these are thick that last longer.
  • 100% Made in India with all raw materials sourced in India
  • Designed with perfect depth to sufficient oil to have it burning for elongated time.
  • Available in Sizes of 3, 3.5, 4,5 Diameters.
Description:
Traditional DMI's two Faced Antique Brass Dasara Pant

  [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] DMI's two Faced Antique Brass Dasara Pant[/caption]  

About Aarti/ Arti:

Panati means mud diya derived from south India. These were usually lit during the Dasara festival. Just like Copper, Brass and silver, mud is also considered to be auspicious. In India lamp are lit daily twice, once in morning and in the evening signifying the ignorance of darkness. But Dasara being the most important among all is popular for lighting diya and keeping it burning continuously for ten days. It is said that Pandavas destroyed Kauravas stating victory over evil. On other hand it is said Goddess Durga won over the asur Mahishasur. With this message we Indians celebrate burning diyas, the so called Panati.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7261,7260,7259,7258"]

Why should we buy this Product?

DMI’s Dasara Panti is made from pure brass (60-65% Copper) material giving it a long lasting finish. This lamp is available with one and two faces. The advantage of double faced diya, is at the time of Dasara (Dassera) festival, when we need to keep it burning continuously for ten days. Either one of two wicks can light without interruption. The modernised touch of the diya completes its ravishing look. Finished with 60-65 % of Copper, this DMI Alang Dhuparti is perfect for gifting or donating to temples. It is designed keeping it simple making it easy to clean.

With an experience of more than 40 years, the company offers a wide range of Brass metal products along with over 100 catalogue products.

Name: DMI's Brass Heat Resistant Cooker Sanchi
Short description:
• This is a Heat Resistant Cooker Sanchi also known as Plier, Chimta, Kitchen Tong or Pakkad.
  • Made of more than 60 % Copper.
  • Cooker Sanchi/ Plier used to lift utensils from Cooker.
  • Being heat resistant these are perfect for serving food safely.
  • 100% Made in India with all raw materials sourced in India.
Description:
DMI's Brass Heat Resistant Cooker Sanchi / Plier / Chimta / Kitchen Tong / Pakkad

  [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] DMI's Brass Heat Resistant Cooker Sanchi[/caption] [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] DMI's Brass Heat Resistant Cooker Sanchi[/caption]  

Story behind pliers

Pliers or tongs are an ancient invention when people were mainly into the process of smiting/casting. This involved melting different metals and moulding them. That is when Pliers were introduced, which gave grip to hold hot materials. These were later used for different purposes which had different designs. Until then women in kitchen used easily available materials for cooking, like holding hot utensils with cloth. But this had a disadvantage of accidentally catching fire. Then pliers from casting came to rescue of women. Cooking and serving was then, much safer than earlier. Lately, pliers are known by different names in different regional languages like Pakkad, Chimta, Kitchen Tong, Utility holder and Sanchi. The basic design of pliers developed as per need and time and is now found of different made of different metals, shapes and sizes.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7318,7317,7316,7315"]

Why should we buy this Product?

DMI an expert in manufacturing brass kitchenware brings you Brass Popat Sanchi and Cooker Sanchi. Being made of 60-65 % of Copper, this is durable, corrosive resistant and can withstand high temperatures. Keeping safety and the thought that ‘Food tastes best when served hot’ DMI has two creations. Both are used for holding utensils, Popat Plier is designed to hold utensils that are flat or oncave shaped like Tawa and while the Cooker Sanchi/ Plier is used to hold handless saucepans from cooker. Those who did love their wives, sisters, friends, mother, would definitely buy this beneficial product, which is a must in your kitchen.

With an experience of more than 40 years, the company offers a wide range of Brass metal products along with over 100 catalogue products.

Name: DMI's 5 Faced Ethnic Brass Divaj or Bhadradeepam
Short description:
• Divaj is the design resulting from combination of lower portion along with handle of Pancharti and Diya.
  • All 5 diya’s have sufficient depth to hold enough oil making it burn for longer duration.
  • This Divaj is unique in design and has 5 Deepa’s with each having a wick stand in the centre
  • Weight: 650 gms | Oil Capacity: 150 ml | Hight: 4.5’’ | Width: 6.25’’ | Length: 10.
  • 100% Made in India with all raw materials sourced in India.
Description:
Traditional DMI's 5 Faced Ethnic Brass Divaj or Bhadradeepam

  [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] DMI's 5 Faced Ethnic Brass Divaj or Bhadradeepam[/caption]  

Significance of Divaj

We have known several reasons for lighting a lamp, during inauguration, before commencing an event or while worshipping at home or in a temple. One such importance is mentioned in Lalitha Sahasranamam. It is stated that a lamp represents Goddess Durga, Saraswathi and Lakshmi. Five faces in a lamp represent 5 qualities a woman needs to have, those are: Affection, Intelligence, Resoluteness, Patience and Caution. The oil in the lamp refers to mind of the woman, thus when a lamp is lit, all the above the qualities gain the importance. Lighting the souls and helping us develop the intellect, this portrays as too why diya’s should be lit. A Lamp with 5 wicksis also known as ‘Bhadradeepam’.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7234,7235,7236,7237"]

Why should we buy this Product?

From the amazing product range of DMI, Panchdeep and Divaj are two unique style diyas. Containing 60-65% quality brass, these make a perfect gifting option for self or near and dear ones. The design is inspired by the Pancharti and Diva, with a centre wick stand. The centre wick stand provided, makes it easy for one to insert diya and avoids leakage of oil too. Additionally, the wick stand is believed to enhance ones concentration. "

Traditional DMI's Authentic Brass DP Diya

 

Why do we light Lamp

Most Hindus light the lamp in front of god, while some others light in the morning and at the dusk and while few of them keep it burning all the time known as Akhanda Jyoti or Akhanda Deepa. Yet few people tend to argue over the comparison on diya and electric lights. However, they fail to understand the spiritual prominence of lighting Divas. It is believed that God first appears in the form of light which is known as ‘Divine light’. By lighting lamp we destroy our intellect enemies like anger, lust, jealousy and greediness. Therefore it is said that lighting lamp at temple enlightens life, while lighting deepa at home lightens our lives.

  [gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7325,7324"]

Why should we buy this Product?

To keep this tradition and tale of diya going DMI has introducted DP Diya to its product range.This product is a perfect blend of convenience and design. The upper portion of the design is inspired by Niranjan with a centre wick stand, whereas the lower portion is encouraged from the Samai. Made up of 60-65 % brass this is just right for gifting or purchasing for self.

Short description:
• This pattern is a combination of samay and dhoopaarti for easy handling of it.
  • The upper portion is designed to hold 1 wick.
  • Perfect for aarti it can hold 20 ml of oil.
  • 100% Made in India with all raw materials sourced in India.

Description:
Traditional DMI's Antique Brass Goa Ekarti designed to hold 1 wick for puja

  [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Shri Dhanlaxmi DMI's Antique Brass Goa Ekarti designed to hold 1 wick for puja[/caption] [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Shri Dhanlaxmi DMI's Antique Brass Goa Ekarti designed to hold 1 wick for puja[/caption]

About Aarti / Arti

Aarti is derived from the Sanskrit word, which means something that removes ratri, darkness. Arti is to have descended from the vedic concept of fire ritual or homa. Everything included in aarti be it flowers or incense sticks each has something to represent. Thus, one’s entire existence and all facets of material creation are symbolically offered to the lord via the aarti ceremony. Aarti signifies that one is peripheral to godhead or divinity. It also serves as a reminder to stay vigilant so that the forces of material pleasures and desires cannot overcome the individual

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7311,7310,7309,7308"]  

Why buy this product?

As the name goes Panchaarti, ‘Panch’ means five, which represent Space (Akash), Wind (Vayu), Fire (Agni), Water (Jal) and Earth (Prithvi) and so does this aarti have five faces. This Panchaarti, completed with 60-65 % of Copper is quite thick, which is durable for a long time. It is designed keeping it simple making it easy to clean. It has the modern touch pleasing to the eye gracing its looks. The cup provided highlights its feature that once the diya lit would burn for extended time. Just as in samay we have 5 faced diya, in panchaarti we have single faced aarti too known as Goa Ekarti and Tulas Ekarti."

Name: DMI's 7 Faced Traditional Brass Goa Lamandeep or Hanging Lamp
Short description:
• This is 7 faced Hanging Lamp also traditionally known as Lamandeep, Kuthuvilakku or Nilavilakku
  • Composes more than 60% of Copper, making it a durable and an inevitable product.
  • The lamp has sufficient depth to hold enough oil making it burn for longer duration.
  • Diva is designed with 7 faces to hold 7 cotton wicks, each representing a direction to be lit.
Description:
DMI's 7 Faced Traditional Brass Goa Lamandeep or Hanging Lamp

  [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Shri Dhanlaxmi DMI's 7 Faced Traditional Brass Goa Lamandeep or Hanging Lamp[/caption] [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Shri Dhanlaxmi DMI's 7 Faced Traditional Brass Goa Lamandeep or Hanging Lamp[/caption]  

Significance of Diya

India has been a country for number of traditions, but each of which is incomplete without the worship of God. Diya means ‘Dextoxify Your Aatma (soul)’, where oil in the diya symbolises the dirt in the human and the cotton wick symbolises the aatma or the self or the soul. The light in the lamp signifies freeing one from all forms of sadness, guiding the path to enlightenment and to connect with the Supreme Being. Definitely there are a number of oils that can be used to light the lamp, which have their own importance, but according to Vastu, lighting the lamp in ghee would be more fruitful than oil. Lamandeep known as Laman Diva in Marathi, are usually brought in pairs, considering them to be auspicious and are lit during special functions. It also believed that the Samay with odd number of faces is considered auspicious.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7302,7301,7298,7299"]

Why buy this product?

Kuthuvilakku or Lamandeep is just another amazing product from the DMI’s range of products. Made of 60-65% quality Copper, this hanging lamp is a long lasting product with perfect shine with each use. This traditional lamp with slight modern touch is one such product which can grace any occasion, be it in the form of gift or self purchase. Or can also be donated to temples/ worship places, which enhance the devotional ambience creating a positive environment adding beauty to the temple doorway.

In addition, Brass is considered as the most holy metal in inducing positive vibes, which makes this diya a perfect option when looking for one.

Name: DMI's 7 Faced Antique Brass Samai Kalas design at centre and lined pattern stand
Short description:
• The Samay is 7 faced with enough depth to hold sufficient oil/ghee to have it burning for long.
  • Dismantling of the parts makes the cleaning process convenient.
  • 100% Made in India with all raw materials sourced in India
  • Available in Sizes of 3.5, 4, 4.5, 5, 5.5 Diameters.
Description:
Traditional DMI's 7 Faced Antique Brass Samai

  [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] DMI's 7 Faced Antique Brass Samai also known as Goa Samai with Kalas design at centre and lined pattern stand[/caption]  

About Aarti/ Arti

It is believed that lamp need not be a visual aid, because we see it makes a different when a lamp is lit. It naturally creates an etheric sphere around the flame. Where there is etheric sphere communication will be better. This phenomenon can be observed in campfire. When people sit around the campfire and listen to stories, their receptivity will be at its best. Thus, if you want to start anything, or you want to create a certain atmosphere, a lamp is lit. This comes from the understanding that when you light a lamp, apart from the visual aspect, it fills the whole place with a different kind of energy. Everything that is driving life in this world is fire. So fire is seen as the very source of life. It also creates a field of energy around itself, and above all it creates the necessary atmosphere. So when you light a lamp before you start your day, it is because you want to bring the same quality into yourself. It is symbolism; it’s a way of invoking your own inner nature.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7266,7263"]  

Why buy this product?

To enhance the above value of Samay, it is designed in two different patterns. One of them has to significant Kalas designed at the center with 7 faces around. Kalas symbolizes abundance and source of life in the Vedas. The other is Mayur Samay which has a fine-looking peacock engraved at the center on the top of it. Both the pillars of the samai have delicate lines carved completing its look which are usually brought in pairs. You would not regret buying or gifting this as it is made with 60-65% of Copper making it durable product."

Short description:

Why do we light Deepa/Diya?

As per the customs followed Diyas are lit daily at homes. There are a number of diyas that are momentous for their design and to be lit at different occasions. According to astrology and shastras the kind of oil used, have various reasons and benefits too. At several places there is a ritual of lighting Akhanda Jyothi (Nandadeep-continuously burning).In relation to Vastu Brass Deepak should be placed in east or west direction. As stated the facing of God is in the east or west direction so diya should be placed adjacent to it. Along with this we need to take care of the number of wicks, lighting a lamp with odd number of wicks like 1, 3, 5 is considered to be fortunate.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7393,7392,7390,7389"]

Why buy this Product?

Brass the so called auspicious metal popularly used for Pooja and other rituals is also known for enhancing the calmness and happiness in adornment. These are usually lit only in temples and divine places. Finished with 60-65 % of Copper, this Nandadeep is perfect for gifting or donating to temples. It is designed keeping it simple making it easy to clean. It has the modern touch pleasing to the eye gracing its looks. The cup provided highlights its feature that once the diya lit would burn for extended time.

Significance of Niranjan

India is known for a diversified culture with a number of religions being followed. Thus worshiping is an integral part of the nation. Worshipping includes a number of items, among which Niranjan is an important one. It holds a special place in every religion, symbolising peace and light to the man. Hence with this significance lamp across every religion in India is lit every day twice, in the morning and evening. Niranjan have added benefits for prayers and health depending on kind of oil or ghee used to lit the Niranjan. And the kind of oil or ghee used again depends on which day it is being lit.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7439,7438,7436,7435"]

This has a centre wick stand provided, making it easier for one to insert the cotton wick, avoiding the side leakage of oil which usually happens with normal diya. The wick stand in the centre is believed to enhance ones concentration.

About Aarti/ Arti

Aarti is derived from the Sanskrit word, which means something that removes ratri, darkness. Arti is to have descended from the vedic concept of fire ritual or homa.Everything included in aarti be it flowers or incense sticks each has something to represent. Thus, one’s entire existence and all facets of material creation are symbolically offered to the lord via the aarti ceremony. Aarti signifies that one is peripheral to godhead or divinity. It also serves as a reminder to stay vigilant so that the forces of material pleasures and desires cannot overcome the individual.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7430,7429,7428,7426"]

Why buy this Product?

As the name goes Panchaarti, ‘Panch’ means five, which represent Space (Akash), Wind (Vayu), Fire (Agni), Water (Jal) and Earth (Prithvi) and so does this aarti have five faces. This Panchaarti, completed with 60-65 % of Copper is quite thick, which is durable for a long time. It is designed keeping it simple making it easy to clean. It has the modern touch pleasing to the eye gracing its looks. The cup provided highlights its feature that once the diya lit would burn for extended time. Just as in samay we have 5 faced diya, in panchaarti we have single faced aarti too known as Goa Ekarti and Tulas Ekarti.

The oil in the lamp refers to mind of the woman, thus when a lamp is lit, all the above the qualities gain the importance. Lighting the souls and helping us develop the intellect, this portrays as too why diya’s should be lit. A Lamp with 5 wicks is also known as ‘Bhadradeepam’.

Name: DMI's Brass Heat Resistant Popat Sanchi
Short description:
• This is a Heat Resistant Popat Sanchi also known as Plier, Chimta, Kitchen Tong or Pakkad.
  • Made of more than 60 % Copper.
  • Cooker Sanchi/ Plier used to lift utensils from Cooker.
  • Being heat resistant these are perfect for serving food safely.

Description:
<h2 style="text-align: center;"DMI's Brass Heat Resistant Popat Sanchi /Plier / Chimta / Kitchen Tong / Pakkad   [caption id="attachment_7101" align="alignnone" width="1200"] DMI's Brass Heat Resistant Popat Sanchi[/caption]  

Story behind pliers

Pliers or tongs are an ancient invention when people were mainly into the process of smiting/casting. This involved melting different metals and moulding them. That is when Pliers were introduced, which gave grip to hold hot materials. These were later used for different purposes which had different designs. Until then women in kitchen used easily available materials for cooking, like holding hot utensils with cloth. But this had a disadvantage of accidentally catching fire. Then pliers from casting came to rescue of women. Cooking and serving was then, much safer than earlier. Lately, pliers are known by different names in different regional languages like Pakkad, Chimta, Kitchen Tong, Utility holder and Sanchi. The basic design of pliers developed as per need and time and is now found of different made of different metals, shapes and sizes

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7407,7406,7405,7404"]

Why buy this Product?

DMI an expert in manufacturing brass kitchenware brings you Brass Popat Sanchi and Cooker Sanchi. Being made of 60-65 % of Copper, this is durable, corrosive resistant and can withstand high temperatures. Keeping safety and the thought that ‘Food tastes best when served hot’ DMI has two creations. Both are used for holding utensils, Popat Plier is designed to hold utensils that are flat or concave shaped like Tawa and while the Cooker Sanchi/ Plier is used to hold handless saucepans from cooker. Those who did love their wives, sisters, friends, mother, would definitely buy this beneficial product, which is a must in your kitchen.

Tale of Vermicelli

When it comes to variety of cuisine, be it in veg or non-veg, India is the country to top the list. With Number of languages, states, religions followed across the country is also blessed to have a diverse taste too. Every day is a festive day and each of them has a certain traditional dish to be cooked with certain significance. One among them is the Vermicelli. Popularly known as Sevai in Tamil is prepared in Tamil Nadu and other South Indian communities as a breakfast or Tiffin. But otherwise when cooked in milk, with dry fruits, sugar or jaggery is served as a desert being known for included in the wedding ceremony rituals. This is usually made with steamed rice dumplings, being an amazing option for the health conscious people. They can make Santhakai or Saemia (western Tamil Nadu) can be made with other doughs like Ragi, Wheat, Jowar and Millet flour.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7386,7385,7384,7382"]

As we know different metals have different significance, so does brass too. Usage of bras utensils is known to benefit our body in number of ways like increasing strength & immunity, helps in pacifying pitta (burning sensations, aggression), increases haemoglobin count, and improves the general condition of your skin. Secondly, made with 60-65 % of Copper, this Shavige press is rust free making it long lasting and user friendly. Dismantling of the press eases the process of cleaning it. It’s a perfect gift for a newlywed couple. Though, we find instant and ready vermicelli, the real taste is in enjoying freshly made savage.

About Aarti/ Arti

Panati means mud diya derived from south India. These were usually lit during the Dasara festival. Just like Copper, Brass and silver, mud is also considered to be auspicious. In India lamp are lit daily twice, once in morning and in the evening signifying the ignorance of darkness. But Dasara being the most important among all is popular for lighting diya and keeping it burning continuously for ten days. It is said that Pandavas destroyed Kauravas stating victory over evil. On other hand it is said Goddess Durga won over the asur Mahishasur. With this message we Indians celebrate burning diyas, the so called Panati.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7339,7338,7337,7340"]

Why buy this Product?

DMI’s Dasara Panti is made from pure brass (60-65% Copper) material giving it a long lasting finish. This lamp is available with one and two faces. The advantage of double faced diya, is at the time of Dasara (Dassera) festival, when we need to keep it burning continuously for ten days. Either one of two wicks can light without interruption. The modernised touch of the diya completes its ravishing look.

About Aarti/ Arti

Panati means mud diya derived from south India. These were usually lit during the Dasara festival. Just like Copper, Brass and silver, mud is also considered to be auspicious. In India lamp are lit daily twice, once in morning and in the evening signifying the ignorance of darkness. But Dasara being the most important among all is popular for lighting diya and keeping it burning continuously for ten days. It is said that Pandavas destroyed Kauravas stating victory over evil. On other hand it is said Goddess Durga won over the asur Mahishasur. With this message we Indians celebrate burning diyas, the so called Panati.

[gallery columns="2" link="none" size="large" ids="7355,7354,7353"]

Why buy this Product?

DMI’s Dasara Panti is made from pure brass (60-65% Copper) material giving it a long lasting finish. This lamp is available with one and two faces. The advantage of double faced diya, is at the time of Dasara (Dassera) festival, when we need to keep it burning continuously for ten days. Either one of two wicks can light without interruption. The modernised touch of the diya completes its ravishing look.
